Content.Name: Research Guide
Content.Title: Research Guide
Content.BodyCopy:
Here you can find specific instructions on how to do research along with a variety of research topics and related materials to help you narrow your research and to find information faster.

Doing Research

When you are searching for information it is hard to decide where to start. From Books, Magazines, Journals, Newspapers, and the World Wide Web it can be difficult to find what you need. Your source choice will influence the kind of information you retrieve. Consider the specific attributes of an information's source before you make a choice. Accurate information, current information, and appropriate information are valuable commodities. Only use information that is backed up by reliable sources.

Don't settle for less. If you are not confident that the information you have retrieved is the most appropriate for your purpose, ask a professional.

The best information source is a librarian and the best access to the highest quality of information is a library. Librarians can help you locate the highest quality information for your research needs, including information that is both relevant, accurate, and reliable. Librarians can also help you locate this information quickly. Libraries have much more information than what is located on the World Wide Web; they provide access to a world of information that is not available on the Internet. Librarians can help you make the best use of all available information resources.

Finding Books

It is estimated that less than 15% of the world's information is digitized. The vast majority of the world's information is available in print-only, much of it published in books. While the Web may be a great source of current information, books are either the best source and/or the only source of other types of information. The key is to know when to search for a book.

Finding books at your local library is simple. Most libraries list the books that they own in a catalog. A library catalog is a record of all the items (books, journal titles, and more) that a library owns. Most libraries store their catalogs on a computer. The catalog provides brief information about the item and information about how you can locate that item in the library. If you see something that you would like in a catalog, a librarian can help you find it.

Brigham Young University-Idaho has a catalog of all the books here in the library located on the library website. The website also provides a variety of research databases that can be searched for information that has been digitized on the World Wide Web.

Finding Articles

To find articles in a library, you'll need to use a database. Databases are indexes that help you locate articles within magazines and journals. These databases provide you with records containing brief bibliographic information (the author, title, journal, date published). Some records also give you an abstract, which is a brief description of the article. Some provide you with a link to the full text of the article, although not all magazine and journal articles are available through the computer.

There are many databases that libraries can pay to access. Check with a librarian at your local library to find out what databases you can access there, and ask for assistance in learning how to search a database.

To search Brigham Young University-Idaho's database you must be a student or faculty member to have access. The databases can be found on the library website at www.lib.byui.edu. You then click on the drop-down menu that reads Articles/News. You can then click on the database you would like to use.

Searching the Web

The World Wide Web is generally accessible, convenient, and frequently fast. It provides wealth of content, but the content can be uneven and difficult to verify. Using the web as your only source is not the best idea. Verifying the information through other sources is a better option. When deciding to use the web as your source, consider the following questions:

  • Are you sacrificing quality for convenience?
  • Is the information more current than other sources?
  • Is the information more authoritative than other sources?
  • Is the information more objective than other sources?
  • Is the information more reliable than other sources?
  • Does it provide unique coverage of your topic?

Search engines are the most common way of searching the web. There are over twenty major search engines, so pick your favorite. A selective list includes: Google, Yahoo, and Bing.

Evaluating Information

Not all information is reliable, objective, or timely. You need to be critical of the information you find. Consider the following questions when evaluating information:

  • Does the scope of your information provide sufficient breadth and depth?
  • Are all aspects of the subject covered? To what level of detail in the subject does the resource go?
  • Is the purpose, audience, accuracy, authority, currency, and quality of your information appropriate for your information need?
  • What is the purpose of the resource? Is the information factual or opinion? Are political or ideological biases apparent?
  • Who is the intended audience for this information? Is it intended for a subject expert or a layperson?
  • Is the information accurate? How do you know?
  • What is the author's expertise, credentials, or institutional affiliation? Are the author's sources of information documented?
  • Is the information in the resource limited to certain time periods?
  • Is the text well-written. Does the author achieve credibility as a result of the quality of presentation and expression?

 Citing sources

Citing your information sources acknowledges the origin of your information, and it lends credibility to your work by showing evidence of your research. It enables your readers to locate your information sources, should they want to.

One resource that is great for all the information you will ever need to cite any source in APA or MLA format can be found at http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/ .

Most of this material was found on the Kentucky Virtual Library website. http://www.kyvl.org/html/tutorial/research/
